_prev_prog_3.Description:
C-611-B

Controls are used to prevent and mitigate chlorine releases and limit employee exposure. The first line of defense is prevention. Employees use both safety equipment and controls to reduce the probability of a chlorine release. These controls range from installation of vacuum regulators to frequent replacement of container valves. The controls also mitigate the release after it has occurred. These mitigation controls include lazy rods, respirators, ventilation systems, detectors, and alarms. The alarms either directly or indirectly initiate emergency response. Employee exposure time is also limited by alarms inside and outside of the facility, providing adequate egress, and eyewash and safety showers nearby.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.  INTRODUCTION



Four Rivers Nuclear Partnership, LLC, (FRNP) has updated the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Paducah Gaseous Diffusion Plant (PGDP) in accordance with requirements set forth in 40 CFR Part 68.  The PGDP facility is subject to Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management Program requirements. This update to the RMP has been prepared to remove the fluorine processes, because fluorine no longer is present at PGDP in quantities exceeding its threshold quantity listed in 40 CFR 68.130. This RMP update also reflects a change in the operator of PGDP from Fluor Federal Services, Inc., to FRNP. Other information in the RMP has been updated as needed.



2.  MANAGEMENT AND ORGANIZATION 



FRNP's policy is to provide a safe and healthy workplace for all people supporting the project. FRNP is dedicated to the belief that all injuries, accidents, and incidents are preventable and is committed to integrating safety and other operational requirements (e.g., environmental, quality, security) into all aspects of work planning and execution.

 

3.  GENERAL DESCRIPTION



3.1  Facility Description and Location



PGDP formerly enriched uranium using the gaseous diffusion process.  PGDP is located at 37.114444 latitude and -88.809167 longitude measured at the approximate center of the plant, on a 3,423-acre tract (and 133 acres in easements) in McCracken County, Kentucky. The site is in a generally rural area and previously was part of Kentucky Ordnance Works.  PGDP occupies approximately 650 acres within the Controlled Access Area. Highway U.S. 60 is the closest major highway and intersects the plant access road 3.5 miles south of the plant. Interstate Highway 24 is to the east of the plant and intersects U.S. 60 near the present city limits of Paducah.  The north, east, and west boundaries of the plant are defined by the West Kentucky Wildlife Management Area.  Adjoining the reserve on the north is the Tennessee Valley A

uthority's Shawnee Fossil Plant, which is located on the Ohio River. The entire PGDP facility is owned by the DOE.  



USEC leased and operated a portion of the PGDP facility for enrichment operations. The leased portion contained the facilities that handled chemicals that required an RMP. USEC ceased enrichment operations and returned the facilities to DOE on October 21, 2014. 



3.2  Regulated Substances



Chlorine is the only substance listed in 40 CFR 68.130 that is present at PGDP in a quantity exceeding its threshold quantity.  Chlorine is managed in accordance with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119, PSM program, as well as the Risk Management Program. Fluorine was present at PGDP in a quantity exceeding its threshold quantity listed in 40 CFR 68.130 and subject to the RMP until January 30, 2018, when the last fluorine tube truck was shipped off-site.   



3.3  Use of Regulated Substances



3.3.1  Chlorine



Raw water is taken from the Ohio River, treated, and supplied to PGDP for numerous uses.  After the chemical softening process, chlorine is used for primary disinfection of the water supply. A portion of the water then is filtered, post-disinfected using chlorine, and then used to supply potable water, fire system water, cooling water, and for other uses.  Raw water treatment takes place at the C-611 Water Treatment Plant, which is located to the west of the plant.  Chlorine is used at two locations at C-611.  

 

4.  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no major releases of chlorine involving injury to site workers, environmental effects, or any impact to the public within the past five years.  



5.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



Chemical safety at PGDP consists of the integration of environmental, safety, and health management systems to address chemical safety.  Chemical safety controls are designed to mitigate the adverse effects of the hazardous materials and toxic substances used in the enrichment process to workers, th

e public, and the environment.  To achieve this objective, safety analyses, process hazard analyses, and industrial hygiene and safety programs are utilized.  PSM Process Hazards Analyses (PHAs) are used to identify and manage chemical risks and impacts.  Specific job-related risks and the technical and administrative controls used for risk management are addressed in the PHAs. 



5.1  Control Systems



Several passive and active control systems are used to minimize the accidental release of chlorine. All chlorine feed facilities utilize a vacuum feed system. The feed systems are equipped with container-mounted vacuum regulators that reduce the pressure of the chlorine from the vapor pressure of the liquid chlorine in the container.  Loss of vacuum for any reason causes the vacuum-regulating valve to close the gas supply, minimizing the release in the event of a break in the manifold.



All chlorine feed facilities are equipped with chlorine detectors, which provide alarms to plant personnel in the event of a release.



Manually operated, remote valve closing rods are administratively required to be in place on the stem of open, 1-ton chlorine container valves.  These valves can be operated from outside of the chlorinator rooms in the event of a release from the manifold system.



5.2  Procedures



Plant procedures are prepared in accordance with the requirements of a formal procedure program.  The procedure program includes the development, review and approval, revision process, distribution, and procedure configuration management.  Specific procedures for the operation and maintenance of the chlorine systems and the handling of storage cylinders are managed within the procedure program.



5.3  Training



Employee training is coordinated by a dedicated training organization.  Personnel who operate, maintain, manage, handle, and have emergency response duties for chemicals covered by PSM are trained adequately for the particular chemical system or related ac

tivity.



5.4  Maintenance and Inspection



The Engineering group, in conjunction with the specific facility maintenance organizations and the manufacturer's recommendations, develops maintenance and inspection requirements and criteria for chemical systems.  These chemical safety requirements are based on PSM program requirements for the particular system.



Maintenance of chemical systems is performed in accordance with the facility maintenance programs that include the PSM Mechanical Integrity program for systems covered under PSM.



Maintenance work packages are prepared to provide the necessary technical and safety guidance for maintenance activities.



5.5  Preventive Maintenance



Manufacturer's recommendations are used as guides for preventive maintenance on specific chemical systems and equipment.  Equipment installed or maintenance services provided by contractors for chemical systems are tested and inspected by the contractor, as required by the contract for that project.  PGDP personnel also perform independent inspection and testing.



5.6  Quality Considerations



Independent overview of maintenance activities on chemical hardware is addressed by the Quality Assurance and Configuration Management programs, as applicable.  These independent programs include the following:



?    Procurement Quality Requirements

?    Construction Inspection

?    Testing and Pre-Operational Inspection

?    Pressure Vessel Inspection

?    Crane Inspection

?    Operational Readiness Review and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs



5.7  Configuration Management 



The Configuration Management (CM) program is applicable to chemical systems.  The plant CM Program includes an organizational structure and administrative process and controls to ensure that accurate, current design documentation is maintained that matches the plant physical configuration.



In accordance with 29 CFR 1910.119(i), a pre-startup safety review is performed for new or modified facilities when the change

is significant enough to require a change to process safety information.  The pre-startup safety review is an independent review to address the readiness of the system hardware, associated hazard controls, personnel (including required training), and procedures.  If the change does not require a change to process safety information, a pre-startup safety review is not performed.



6.  EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM



The purpose of the Paducah Site Emergency Management (EM) Program, as outlined in the Paducah Site EM Plan and associated implementing procedures, is to create an integrated and comprehensive EM System at the Paducah Site to ensure the following:



?    Paducah Site can respond effectively and efficiently to emergencies of any severity to ensure the consequences of all emergencies are minimized, and appropriate response measures are

        taken to protect the health and safety of all workers and the public, protect the environment, and protect national security;

?    Emergencies are recognized, categorized, classified promptly, as necessary, and parameters associated with the emergency are monitored to detect changed or degraded conditions;

?    Emergencies are reported and notifications are made promptly and accurately, and effective initial and ongoing communications are made to site personnel and the public;

?    Reentry activities are properly and safely accomplished as outlined in site safety plans, and recovery and post-emergency activities commence properly; and

?    Recovery to normal site work activities is well planned in advance of terminating from an emergency. 



6.1  Organization



FRNP is responsible for the DOE Paducah Site Emergency Response Organization (ERO). The ERO is a structured organization with overall responsibility for initial and ongoing emergency response and mitigation. The ERO establishes effective control at the scene of an event/incident and integrates ERO activities with those of local agencies and organizations that provide

on-site response services. An adequate number of experienced and trained personnel, including designated alternates, are available on demand for timely and effective performance of ERO functions. The ERO is staffed by personnel with site experience and knowledge who respond to events. The ERO members are required to participate in formal training (initial and refresher), drills, and exercises. Site-level ERO elements and resources participate in a minimum of one exercise annually.



6.2  Emergency Response Organization Actions



The ERO initially consists of the Plant Shift Superintendent (PSS), Fire Services, Emergency Medical Support, and E-Squad with the PSS or another qualified individual as the IC at the scene. Upon declaration of an OE or a classified emergency (Alert or SAE), the PSS becomes the Crisis Manager (CM) and maintains overall control of the emergency response until relieved. 



ERO is divided into three functional groups, namely, on-scene field response, Emergency Operations Center (EOC), and Joint Information Center (JIC). The on-scene field response is comprised of Paducah Site personnel who respond to the incident scene. Within the field responders are personnel who are experienced and trained in incident assessment, incident mitigation, radiological control, industrial hygiene monitoring, work coverage, decontamination, environmental response, etc.  Fire/explosion, rescue, and HAZMAT responses are performed by FRNP Fire Services personnel. In addition to fire, rescue, and HAZMAT response, fire services personnel also are trained in emergency medical treatment. Advanced Life Support (ALS) is provided by paramedics.



6.3  Emergency Response Equipment

 

Emergency response equipment at DOE Paducah Site includes the following:



?    Communication Equipment

?    Decontamination Equipment

?    Alarm Equipment

?    Rescue Team Equipment

?    Sanitation and Survival Equipment

?    Transportation Equipment

?    Gas and Liquid Monitoring Equipment

?    Damage Con

trol Equipment

?    Fire Fighting Equipment



6.4  Training



The ERO receives training commensurate with assigned positions.  A formal training program that includes classroom-type training (lectures, seminars); practical applications (tabletop drills, functional drills, and exercises); and self-study programs has been developed for the ERO and support personnel. The training program ensures the continued EM response competency of all persons who may respond/participate during an emergency. Specialized emergency management training is provided and includes, but is not limited, to the following categories and topics:



?    On-Scene Response Activities-Topics covered include incident command, firefighting, HAZMAT response, including monitoring and emergency medical technician training.

?    Emergency Management Orientation- Topics covered include concept of operations, emergency organizations, responsibilities and authorities, requirements, facilities and equipment overview, and offsite interface summary including public information.

?    Incident Classification and Notification-Topics covered include classification systems, notification requirements, procedures, and emergency action levels.

?    Hazard/Consequence Assessments and Protective Actions-Topics covered include the spectrum of hazards and possible emergencies as well as reference material, site profile information, and site dispersion models. On-site and off-site protective actions and protective action decision-making philosophy are covered as well as recovery decision making.

?    Ongoing Incident Assessment-Topics covered include on-site incident monitoring, off-site field monitoring, personnel protection, and reporting.



Specific emergency training requirements are defined, documented, and tracked for each position. This includes the specific training lessons, frequency of retraining, and the number of hours of initial and retraining that are provided to the ERO.



6.5  Drills



ERO members to include emerg

ency response personnel (such as fire, HAZMAT, emergency medical services) must participate at least annually in a drill, exercise, or actual incident.



6.6  Public Warning System



The public warning system, consisting of outdoor warning sirens and emergency alert systems announcements, is used to provide emergency notification.  Operational testing of the public warning system sirens is conducted monthly.



6.7  Coordination With Off-Site Organizations



Mutual aid agreements, memorandums of understanding, and letters of assistance have been entered into with off-site groups to provide assistance in the event of an emergency.  These support services encompass areas such as medical assistance, fire control, evacuation, ambulance services, and law enforcement.



The Emergency Management organization coordinates required emergency planning activities with state and local agencies, including the Kentucky Division of Emergency Management and the McCracken County Office of Emergency Management.  Emergency planning, drills, and exercises also are coordinated with DOE.
